column3: At the top of the social structure was pharaohs and gods. The pharaohs were in charge of everyone and had absolute power. They also had many responsibilities such as directing armies in case of attack. In the text it states, "Because the people of Egypt believed that their pharaohs were gods, they entrusted their rulers with many responsibilities" (p3). Below them were nobles such as priests, government officials and scribes. Nobles were the only ones that could hold government positions. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods, scribes kept government records and chief ministers called "viziers" ensured taxes were collected. In the text it explains, "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes"(p6). Below them were soldiers, craftsmen, merchants and physicians. column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  Sure, here is the reworded passage:  "The factory used various methods to deceive customers about the quality of their products. Evidence supporting this method was identified through analysis of discarded materials that supported the fact that the ingredients were mixed together in significant proportions and used for food production. Additionally, Jonas's testimony about the smell of spoiled meat on free-lunch counters, where it was often served with soda, lends credibility to the claim that the factory used similar methods to mask the undesirable quality."

column3: One way the factories would use or cover up spoiled meat is the pickle method. The meat taken out of pickle would often be sour and spoiled. It would also have a very strong smell. They would use soda to take away the smell and sell it as fresh meat. Nother way they would use old meat was by extracting the bone and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. The "bonless ham" they claimed it to be, wasnt really bonless ham. It was "all the odds and end of pork stuffed into casings; and "California hams", which were shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out;..." (Sinclair 2). Sausages that were white and moldy wouldnt go to waste. Instead they would get shipped to us from Europe and from there the workers would infuse borax and glycerin into them so it would be all good again for "consuming".
column4: Factories used various methods to deal with spoiled meat. One method involved using pickles to preserve the meat, producing a sour and spoiled taste, strong smell, and potentially affecting its ability to be consumed. Another method involved extracting the bone, inserting it into the flesh, and then cooking it to create "boneless ham". This method, however, resulted in misleading advertisements claiming the meat was actually completely boneless, which was not the case. White and moldy sausages were shipped in from Europe and infused with borax and glycerin to restore their quality for consumption.

column3: In the article, Excerpt From The Jungle, there were many ways factories tried to cover up spoiled meat. Throughout this article it tells us that no matter the color, flavor, or smell they would still sell the meat. These factories didn't care for the health of their consumers and only wanted to make money, so they sold every piece of meat that they could. While reading this article it sounds like they would never let a single piece of meat go to waste even if it was spoiled and covered in mold. In the article it states, ‚Äúold sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white ‚Äì it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.‚Äù(3). This quote from the article explains to us how they covered up the molded meat by using strong and toxic chemicals to get rid of the smell and turn the meat back to brown. The factories had no health regulations, the meat was stored in places infested with germs. The factories knew how filthy their facility was and had put no effort in  to change it. In paragraph 4 it states, ‚ÄúThere would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs.‚Äù(4). This tells us how nobody cared about the condition the meat was in and how no one enforced them to follow any guidelines that had been put in place. Workers knew that what they were doing was wrong and never second guessed it, ‚Äúa man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.‚Äù(4). This quote from the article tells the reader how they used rat meat for sausages. These rats contained many diseases and carried poison from eating contaminated  bread. Which they thought was right to feed  humans. In the factories, spoiled meat was covered up badly. Instead of throwing away the rotting meat they found ways to use it to seem consumable to humanity while they were making it much worse.
column4: Sure, here's the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "Excerpt From The Jungle reveals a disturbing trend in meat processing. Despite their efforts, factories consistently disregarded the quality and freshness of their products, prioritizing profit over the well-being of their consumers. It is evident that the factories were more concerned with maximizing their sales than ensuring the safety and health of their customers.  One particular passage, "old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white - it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption," paints a grim picture of how factories covered up spoiled meat by using potent chemicals. Their lack of health regulations allowed them to employ harsh treatments that transformed perfectly edible meat into something unrecognizable.  The passage also describes the appalling conditions in which the meat was stored. It highlighted the rampant presence of germs and the unsanitary environment that existed in the factories. Employees were indifferent to the safety risks associated with the practice of covering up spoiled meat, further showcasing the disregard for the well-being of consumers.  Furthermore, the article mentions the accidental contamination of meat with rat droppings. It was clear that the factories were not mindful of the potential health risks associated with feeding contaminated food to humans. It is evident that the purpose of covering up spoiled meat was not to ensure food safety but to maintain production efficiency and deceive consumers into thinking that the meat was perfectly fine."

column3: In the social pyramid of ancient Egypt the pharaoh and those associated with divinity were at the top, and servants and slaves made up the bottom. The Egyptians also elevated some human beings to gods. Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects. For example, paragraph 1 it states "Egyptian society was structured like a pyramid." This quote shows that the Egyptian structured government ressembles how the pyramids were built. And goes by the rules and expectations of "the gods." Ancient Egypt had three main social classes--upper, middle, and lower. The upper class consisted of the royal family, rich landowners, government officials, important priests and army officers, and doctors. The middle class was made up chiefly of merchants, manufacturers, and artisans.
column4: The ancient Egyptian social hierarchy, as depicted in ancient texts, placed pharaohs and high-ranking individuals atop the pyramid, while servants and slaves occupied the bottom. This structure reflected the belief in divinely ordained authority. Notably, pharaohs were considered to be akin to gods in human form, wielding absolute power over their subjects. The pyramid's construction mirrored the hierarchical framework of the social pyramid. Additionally, ancient society consisted of three distinct social classes: upper, middle, and lower, each with specific roles and expectations.

column3: Ideal tragedies should consist of many elements. One element is that the plot should should be focused on a single issue as opposed to having two or more. Also, tragedies should not contain characters that transition from bad to good. Instead it should be from good to bad. This transition should be caused by some problem or error. Another element is the emotions is should create. These emotions should be pity and fear. This is caused by how the tragedy is arranged, The arrangement should be complex, not simple.
column4: Ideal tragedies should have a focused plot on a single problem or issue rather than multiple issues. Tragedy should not feature characters that change from good to bad. Instead, the protagonist's emotional journey should shift from positive to negative due to a struggle with a problem or error. The tragedy should have a complex, nuanced plot that is not a simple one-dimensional plot.

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy described by Aristotle are plot, character, diction. The plot is essential to a tragedy, needing a beginning, middle, and an end. Diction in an ideal tragedy is the language or expression by how the characters reveal their thoughts and feelings.
column4: Aristotle's ideal tragedy is defined by three essential elements: plot, character, and diction. A plot is central to a tragedy, with a beginning, middle, and end. column3: One element of an ideal tragedy is that it shouldn't be simple but rather a complex plan. Also, a tragedy should cause the audience to feel pity and fear.  If it doesn't evoke these emotions in the audience then it isn't a real tragedy. A true tragedy should have a plot that doesn't just satisfy the moral sense. A tragedy should not have a poor/bad man turn to prosperity or showcase the downfall of a villain. Instead, a tragedy should contain a character who is not famously good and whose misfortune is brought about by a judgment error or weakness.  Another element is that the plot should be single in its issues rather than double. Also, the change in fortune should not be from bad to good but reverse from good to bad.  As previously discussed this downfall should come from a great error or weakness instead of a vice.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  A tragedy should be complex and intricate, evoking a sense of both pity and fear in the audience. It should have a well-developed plot that explores moral dilemmas and weaknesses in characters. The story should shift from good to bad, highlighting the consequence of unchecked flaws and judgment errors. It should avoid double-layered narratives and have a clear, focused plot with a single central conflict.

column3: Aristole states that the 3 elements of tragedy include wrong judgement, the overcoming of a villian, and fortune. The main character must experience fortune to start of his/her journey. This is the reason the tradedy was created and the foundation for the events that are soon to follow. He/she must also experience a victory of a villian. This is when a main charcter finally overcomes their obsticles and gets to celebrate. The last element is wrong judgement, this is the reason for the main charcter's tragedy. This element includes the main character getting everything he/she worked for but then making on mistake that usally leads to their death and the end of the story.
column4: Aristole believed that tragedy consists of three components: wrong judgment, vanquishing a villain, and experiencing fortune. A protagonist must encounter fortune to initiate his or her journey, and this is the driving force behind the subsequent events. They must also conquer a villain, as this signifies the protagonist's triumph over adversity. Finally, they must experience a climactic victory over a villain to reach a resolution and celebrate their hard-earned triumphs. If the protagonist fails to do so, the consequences will be disastrous, with the protagonist losing everything they

column3: First, Aristotle mentions that a good tragedy has a complicated plot, that "excites pity and fear," (line 10). He then describes that a mistake should be the thing that causes dispair and grief in the life of the character. Then, he describes how the "change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad."

column3: Aristotle tells us many elements of tragedy, which include plot, character, thought, ect. Plot is what I believe to be the most important of all of the elemts described by Aristotle. He believes changes within plot should go from good to bad to reveal aspects about character. Character is another element of tradgedies. A tradgedy needs to be of one who has done or suffered something terrible to enhance the plot. Finally, thought is another compelling aspect to a tradgedy as explained by Aristotle. A tradgedy must challenege the audience to think and and be constructed in a sense where there are surprises, foreshadows, and deep thought that entrances the reader.
column4: Aristotle's teachings on tragedy encompass various elements such as plot, character, thought, and so on. Among these, he emphasizes plot as the most essential of the elements. He believes that plot changes should flow from good to bad to unveil essential aspects of character. Additionally, Aristotle considers character a vital element in tragedy. A tragic play must feature a character who has experienced a traumatic event and therefore has depth and substance in their character. Furthermore, Aristotle emphasizes the importance of thought in tragedy. A tragic play must challenge

column3: In the Egypt goverment they entrusted the leader with many things. Such as protecting them and collecting there taxes the pharaoh  assigned a person to make sure the taxes were collected called a visier. The visier had workers called scribes who kept the records of the goverment. The scribes knew how to read and write. There was also priests who were in charge of pleasing the gods. All of these people assigned with these roles were very rich. Under the Nobles were soldiers who fought in war and protected the area. At the bottom of the social structure was slaves and farmers.
column4: The Egyptian government entrusted its leader with a wide range of responsibilities. Among these was the protection of the leader and the collection of taxes by a designated official known as a visier. The visier's responsibilities were overseen by scribes, who kept records of the government's activities. The scribes were highly skilled individuals who possessed the ability to read and write.
